abstract: In the wake of the financial crisis, when rating agencies were blamed for feeding a subprime mortgage frenzy, Congress used the Dodd-Frank Act to adopt a battery of changes for the rating industry.
snippet: In the wake of the financial crisis, when rating agencies were blamed for feeding a subprime mortgage frenzy, Congress used the Dodd-Frank Act to adopt a battery of changes for the rating industry.
lead_paragraph: It cost $1.37 billion, but Standard & Poor’s has finally appeared to close the darkest chapter in its 150-year history as a rating agency.

headline.main: S.&P. Settlement Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings
headline.print_headline: S.&P. Deal Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper

abstract: S.&P.’s settlement leaves the future unclear for ratings. | A lesson for deal makers. | Smucker announces it will buy Big Heart Pet Brands. | Staples and Office Depot are in advanced talks to combine.
snippet: S.&P.’s settlement leaves the future unclear for ratings. | A lesson for deal makers. | Smucker announces it will buy Big Heart Pet Brands. | Staples and Office Depot are in advanced talks to combine.
lead_paragraph: WHAT S.&P.’S SETTLEMENT MEANS | Standard & Poor’s $1.37 billion settlement with prosecutors, announced on Tuesday, will settle an array of government lawsuits against the giant rating agency. But it does not represent closure for the broader ratings business, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report. An uncertain future still lies ahead for S.&P., as well as its main rivals, Moody’s and Fitch.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: What S.&P.’s Settlement Means
